text: Hi everyone ,I am planning to pitch a proposal for a content marketing partnership (e.g blogs, editorial calendar)with a few health insurance companies over here in Australia. Am still new to this and want to know what details should I include in the proposal?

elements.text: Hi everyone ,I am planning to pitch a proposal for a content marketing partnership (e.g blogs, editorial calendar)with a few health insurance companies over here in Australia. Am still new to this and want to know what details should I include in the proposal?

text: Hi Collen! Have you had a conversation with them about their specific goals? You should build a proposal around that and how you plan to achieve those goals. Explain your process and what makes it different from other options. Show case studies of how this has worked in the past for any other clients so they can visualize what success will look like and get proof you know what you're doing.

elements.text: Hi Collen! Have you had a conversation with them about their specific goals? You should build a proposal around that and how you plan to achieve those goals. Explain your process and what makes it different from other options. Show case studies of how this has worked in the past for any other clients so they can visualize what success will look like and get proof you know what you're doing.

text:
It's easy to write TOO MUCH. Your proposal should be detailed, but everything should be from a perspective of "Will the company I'm pitching understand what I'm saying here?" Leave out details that would be unnecessary or confusing to a non-content marketer.

Another pro tip I learned the hard way: Don't give away all the answers in your proposal. If possible, write it in such a way where they understand the deliverables you're recommending BUT don't just take your proposal and take the free work and do it in-house.
